repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Electricity Sector Efficiency
            Enhancement Project and Energy Sector Recovery Development
            Policy Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Electricity Sector
            Efficiency Enhancement Project; and Energy Sector Recovery
            Development Policy Credit Project for Senegal was as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: proper
            sequencing of sector policy dialogue and investment support
            is important for success when the two are closely connected.
            The Bank has an important role in ensuring that investment
            decisions are made based on technical, financial, and
            economic merits. Where a country's political timetable
            is liable to bring significant shifts in policy, a keen
            appreciation of political economy is necessary. The Bank has
            much to gain from locating key operational staff in the
            field, particularly where a continuous and intense dialogue
            is required, such as Senegal's energy sector.
            Inattention to the good practice principles for the
            application of conditionality can result in policy-based
            operations that are unbalanced and lack focus. In designing
            policy-based operations, a realistic sense of the pace of
            reform will take account of political economy considerations.

18346889.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Rural development

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Electricity Sector Efficiency
            Enhancement (APL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Electricity Sector
            Efficiency Enhancement (APL) Project for Senegal were as
            follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was high; Bank performance was unsatisfactory and
            borrower performance was also unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: small but too ambitious project with
            regard to significant sector needs. The electricity sector
            in Senegal has gone through significant transformation. The
            institutional arrangement should have been designed in
            accordance with the beneficiaries of the main activities and
            the roles and responsibilities of each entity. An important
            lesson learned in many projects implemented by field based
            staff is that the rapidly changing circumstances of the
            sector required an intensive and continuous dialogue which
            becomes easier with the presence of sector teams in the
            field office. Another lesson learned through this project is
            that appropriate field based dialogue and supervision is
            only possible if human resources are adequate. When the team
            is overloaded, the quality of implementation of smaller
            projects could suffer. It serves no useful purpose to impose
            financial covenants that have little chance of being
            achieved. Financial covenants imposed on utilities in Bank
            supported projects often were not met.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Electricity Sector Efficiency
            Enhancement Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objectives of the
            Electricity Sector Efficiency Enhancement Project are to
            help the Borrower to assist in maintaining and increasing
            the electricity supply and the reliability and
            cost-effectiveness of electricity services; and to enhance
            the performance of key institutions of the energy sector.
            The restructuring will consist of a partial cancellation of
            the credit and a reallocation between credit categories, as
            requested by the Government of Senegal (GoS). The
            cancellation of the project subcomponent does not change the
            Project Development Objectives (PDO). A first extension of
            the credit closing date was granted from January 31, 2009 to
            December 31, 2010. To date the amount of US$ 4,646,908.21
            has been disbursed. To date rehabilitation/reinforcement
            works in generation and transmission have not started due to
            delays in: 1) the selection of investments by SENELEC
            (Societe Nationale d'Electricite - National Power
            Utility of Senegal) in view of insufficient funding and; 2)
            the preparation of bidding documents once the choice was made.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Electricity Sector Efficiency
            Enhancement (APL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Senegal Electricity Sector
            Efficiency Enhancement Project aims to: (1) maintain and
            increase the electricity supply and the reliability of the
            services; (2) reduce the costs of the electricity services;
            and (3) enhance the performance of key energy sector
            institutions.  The Project includes two components: Part A
            focuses on priority activities that will allow the
            commission for Senegal's National Power Utility
            (SENELEC) new generation facilities through an independent
            power producer; rehabilitate critical sections of the
            transmission and distribution systems; and reduce costs. It
            also supports the government and SENELEC in preparing the
            next phase of investment in the energy sector.  Part B would
            provide financial resources to support the government's
            efforts to strengthen the institutions; implement
            public/private partnership arrangements for SENELEC; and for
            communication and monitoring and evaluation of project implementation.
